DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Official Fails to Arrange Iran-Iraq Prisoner Swap
DOC.TEXT: A senior Red Cross official flew to Geneva on Wednesday after failing to arrange an immediate swap of ailing and wounded prisoners held by Iran and Iraq more than a year after their cease-fire. Angelo Gnadinger, the Middle East chief of the Geneva-based International Committee of the Red Cross, ended his visit after five days of talks in the Iraqi capital. He held similar meetings last week in Tehran with Iranian officials, seeking the repatriation of 1,000 wounded and ailing prisoners held by both sides. Gnadinger refused to comment to reporters on the outcome of his visit before his departure. But Andreas Wigger, the chief Red Cross delegate in Baghdad, said, ``I may say nothing concrete has been achieved. ... This is a long process which needs more effort.'' Gnadinger had hoped for an immediate release of the sick and wounded as a first step toward settling the issue of the Iranian and Iraqi prisoners of war under article 118 of the Third Geneva Convention. The article calls for repatriation of POWs immediately after hostilities cease. The Red Cross has registered some 50,000 prisoners held by Iran and more than 19,500 in Iraqi camps. Many of the POWs have been held since the early stages of the war that broke out in September 1980. However, diplomats and United Nations officials say the two sides hold 100,000 POWs between them. Last year, Iran and Iraq released about 400 sick and wounded prisoners. But the operation was stopped when both sides accused the other of falsifying the number of captives seeking asylum. Earlier this week, hopes were raised that an agreement for a prisoner swap was imminent. Akram al-Witri, chief of the legal department at the Iraqi Foreign Ministry, said Baghdad had responded positively to a Red Cross call to this effect. But Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati quickly reiterated the Iranian position, undermining the effort. Tehran has insisted it will not agree to swap the prisoners or implement any other peace move with Iraq until Iraqi troops withdraw from land they occupied in the final weeks of the war. A U.N.-sponsored cease-fire halted hostilities on Aug. 20, 1988, but peace talks have been deadlocked mainly over the withdrawal issue and Iraq's demand for a border demarcation accord that gives it sovereignty over the entire Shatt-Al-Arab waterway. The channel, a confluence of the great Tigris and Euphrates rivers, is Iraq's sole gateway to the gulf. Before the war, the border ran down the middle of Shatt-Al-Arab.
